Description: Rim sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice or Type B1 kantharos; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; part of lotus flower in added red and white; top of rom glazed; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The size of the sherd, the lack of diagnostic features and the absence of decoration on the interior and exterior surfaces make it impossible to determine whether it comes from a kantharos or a chalice. Chalice Style chalices (including patterned chalices) have little decoration on their interior and exterior. Given the size of the sherd, it may come from an undecorated part of the chalice. Kantharoi Type B (See Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983, 169) also have very little decoration. Kantharoi Type B1 have lotus flowers and lotus buds on the interior above two white bands.
Bibliographic references: Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 737, no. 974)
CVA Cambridge I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 6, Cambridge, Fasc. 1 (p. 34, no. 34, pl. XVII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1519) (phase 2)
